executive_summary: 2025 saw reasoning models become standard practice, dramatically improving AI performance across math, coding, and robotics but at significant computational cost. Meta triggered an unprecedented talent war with packages up to $300M over 4 years, forcing all major players to dramatically increase AI engineer compensation. The industry committed over $300B this year alone to data center buildout, with projections of $5.2T by 2030, representing infrastructure spending at industrial scale.

stories.title: Reasoning Models Become Standard with Major Performance Gains
stories.summary: Reasoning models that 'think step by step' became mainstream in 2025, with DeepSeek-R1 showing the world how to build them after OpenAI's o1. Performance improvements were dramatic: o1-preview beat GPT-4o by 43 points on math problems and 22 points on PhD-level science questions.
key_facts: Gemini 3 Flash with reasoning uses 160M tokens vs 7.4M without reasoning
Claude Opus 4.5 uses 48M tokens vs GPT-5.1's 81M for same performance
ThinkAct robotics model showed 8% improvement over non-reasoning models
stories.google_implications: Google needs to balance reasoning capability gains against massive token cost increases in Gemini. The 20x+ token usage could significantly impact inference economics and user experience latency.

stories.title: Meta Triggers AI Talent War with $300M Packages
stories.summary: Meta's July launch of Superintelligence Labs with packages up to $300M over 4 years disrupted traditional compensation structures. Zuckerberg personally recruited with house visits, targeting OpenAI, Google, and Anthropic researchers with liquid cash bonuses exceeding typical stock options.
key_facts: Andrew Tulloch initially turned down $1.5B bonus package from Meta
Ruoming Pang's Meta package exceeded pay of top Apple leaders below CEO
xAI hired over a dozen researchers from Meta in response
stories.google_implications: Google faces continued talent pressure and must reassess compensation strategy. DeepMind's historical $345K per employee cost now looks modest compared to current market rates approaching $1M+ for top talent.

stories.title: AI Infrastructure Spending Reaches Industrial Scale
stories.summary: AI industry capital spending topped $300B in 2025 alone for data center construction, with McKinsey projecting $5.2T by 2030. OpenAI's Stargate project represents $500B investment, with each gigawatt of capacity costing roughly $50B to build.
key_facts: $300B spent on AI data centers in 2025
stories.google_implications: Google's infrastructure investments must scale dramatically to remain competitive. The industrial-scale spending suggests AI infrastructure is becoming a core economic driver requiring massive capital allocation.

trend_signals.evidence: All new major models now incorporate reasoning capabilities by default, with performance gains justifying 20x+ token costs
Compensation packages now resemble professional sports with liquid bonuses, equity acceleration, and retention payments exceeding $1M
AI data center construction representing hundreds of billions annually is becoming measurable portion of economic activity

action_items: Reassess Google's AI talent retention strategy given Meta's $300M packages and liquid compensation approach
Evaluate Gemini reasoning token economics - 160M vs 7.4M tokens represents major cost structure change
Benchmark Google's infrastructure capital allocation against industry's $5.2T projected spending through 2030
Monitor DeepSeek-R1 technical details as open alternative to proprietary reasoning models
Track reasoning model efficiency improvements - Claude vs GPT token usage gaps suggest optimization opportunities

links_worth_following.reason: Technical details on how to build reasoning models could inform Google's competitive response
McKinsey's $5.2T infrastructure projection methodology would help calibrate Google's capital planning
Wall Street Journal's talent war coverage likely contains additional compensation benchmarks
